title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. The "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996" addresses judicial review, allowing affected small entities to petition for review of final rules within one year of certification or analysis by an agency. Courts with jurisdiction over rule compliance can review certifications or analyses, even in cases of delayed regulatory flexibility analysis. The Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996 allows affected small entities to petition for judicial review within one year of a regulatory flexibility analysis. Courts can review certifications or analyses and order corrective actions if necessary. The Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996 allows small entities to petition for judicial review within one year. Courts can order corrective actions if the final regulatory flexibility analysis was not prepared correctly. If the agency fails to comply, the court may stay the rule or grant appropriate relief. The court must consider the rule of prejudicial error when making determinations. The court must consider the rule of prejudicial error when making determinations or granting relief in judicial review of a rule. Any regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule will be part of the record for review. Judicial review of impact statements required by other laws is not barred. The amendment applies to final agency rules issued after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 3. RULES COMMENTED ON BY SBA CHIEF COUNSEL FOR ADVOCACY. The SBA Chief Counsel for Advocacy must receive proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis from agencies before publication. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy must receive proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis from agencies. The Chief Counsel may transmit a statement of the effect of the proposed rule on small entities. If a statement is transmitted, the agency must publish it along with their response in the Federal Register. Proposed rules by certain federal agencies must follow this special rule. The text chunk states that certain agencies are exempt from specific requirements in connection with monetary policy, safety of depository institutions, credit unions, and government housing enterprises. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to a section of the United States Code. Congress believes that the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration should have the ability to appear as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
